stimulusHtml: Is there a force exerted by the magnet on the loop as the magnet falls through it? Why or why not?

features.html: A loop of wire is connected to an ammeter, as shown above, and held in place. The ammeter has a scale with zero in the middle and a needle that moves away from zero in either direction to measure the magnitude and direction of any current in the loop. A bar magnet is held above the center of the loop and released from rest.

choicesHtml: No. Because the loop is not magnetized, it will not be affected by the magnet.
No. Because the loop is not moving, there are no forces on it.
Yes. Because the magnetic field due to current in the loop exerts a force on the magnet, the magnet also exerts a force on the loop.
Yes. Because gravity acts on the loop, the magnet must exert a force on the loop to keep it at rest.
